facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in a reference made to it by the Income-tax App

facts.text: The reference was made to the High Court by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: The question of law referred was: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, section 23A was properly applied?

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, section 23A was properly applied?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, section 23A was properly applied ? The relevant facts and circumstances are as follows.

issues.text: whether the dividend declared was less than 60% of the assessable income minus the taxes, and the first condition relevant to the application of section 23A was satisfied

anchor.surface_text: The High Court first held that on the figures the dividend declared was less than 60 of the assessable income minus the taxes, and the first condition relevant to the application of section 23A was, therefore, satisfied. Then the High Court considered the question whether,

issues.text: whether, having regard to the profits made, i.e., profits as distinct from assessable income, the assessee company could or could not have reasonably declared a larger dividend

anchor.surface_text: He then considered the point whether having regard to the profits made, i.e., profits as distinct from assessable income, the assessee company could or could not have reasonably declared a larger dividend. For this purpose, he extracted the following relevant figures Rs. Book profit before appropriation of income-tax, etc.

issues.text: whether the concealed profits totalling nearly Rs. 40,000 had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the correct figure of the profits of the assessee

anchor.surface_text: The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits.

issues.text: whether the additions in respect of luggage collections and expenditure on spare parts, tyres, tubes, etc., disallowed should be added to the book profits because they represent only notional income

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Srinivasan raised two contentions before us first that the additions in respect of luggage collections and expenditure on spare parts, tyres, tubes, etc., disallowed should not be added to the book profits because they represent only notional income.

issues.text: whether the Income-tax Officer had considered the question of reasonableness or unreasonableness of the amount distributed as dividend from the standpoint of business considerations such as previous losses, the present profits, the availability of surplus money and the reasonable requirements of the future

anchor.surface_text: One of his contentions before us was that the Income-tax Officer had not considered the question of reasonableness or unreasonableness of the amount distributed as dividend from the standpoint of business considerations such as previous losses, the present profits, the availability of surplus money and the reasonable requirements of the future, etc.

issues.text: whether having regard to the losses incurred by the company in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made, the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would be unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: He further urged before us that this Court had held in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee & Co. that the burden lay upon the revenue to prove that all the conditions laid down in section 23A were satisfied before the order was made, and he said that one of the conditions was that the Income-tax Officer, after having examined the question, was satisfied that having regard to the losses incurred by the company in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would not be unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: On the scrutiny of these figures he came to the conclusion that section 23A of the Act was applicable because the dividend declared was less than 60 of the profits available for distribution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hown at a lesser figure by inflation of the first and the third items and suppression of the second item. In view of these companysiderations, the App

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court held first condition satisfied; Supreme Court agrees with High Court

arguments.claim: Having regard to profits made (book profits Rs.20,373 after tax), assessee could reasonably have declared larger dividend than Rs.45,000, especially considering additions of Rs.45,000 due to poor maintenance of books

anchor.surface_text: He then considered the point whether having regard to the profits made, i.e., profits as distinct from assessable income, the assessee company could or could not have reasonably declared a larger dividend. For this purpose, he extracted the following relevant figures Rs. Book profit before appropriation of income-tax, etc. 1,01,902 Less Taxes actually payable on total income as finally determined on appeal 81,529 Profits available for distribution 20,373 Dividends declared by the company 45,000 He felt these figures showed that the assessee company could not reasonably have declared dividend of more than Rs. 20,373, but he observed In the case of banking companies or companies with income from property, the computation of income for purposes of the Income-tax Act may in some cases be different from that adopted by the companies themselves. Hence, there may be variation between the assessable income and profits made. In such cases, if the companies are asked to declare dividends on the basis of assessable income, the companies may be forced to declare dividends out of capital which is prohibited under the Companies Act. In this case the difference between the assessable income and profits made is not due to any such variation on the basis of any different statutory of luggage collections and to the addition of Rs. 20,000 made on account of luggage collections and to the addition of Rs. 25,000 on account of spare parts, etc. These additions have been sustained by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. This clearly shows that the books are not so properly maintained as to deduce the distributable income from the assessee companys book profits. Moreover if the additions of Rs. 45,000 are made to the profits of Rs. 20,373 available for distribution, the company could very well have declared a larger dividend than what has been actually declared by it. I, therefore, apply the provisions of section 23A.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that section 23A properly applied

arguments.claim: Difference between assessable income and book profits due to inflated expenditure on spare parts (Rs.25,000), suppressed luggage collections (Rs.15,000), and depreciation difference (Rs.34,906); directors aware of real profits

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner found on analysis that the difference of nearly a lakh of rupees between the total income as finally determined, namely, Rs. 2,04,222 and the book profits amounting to Rs. 1,01,902 was principally due to the following additions made in the assessment Rs. Spare parts, tyres, tubes, etc. 25,000 Suppression of luggage collections 15,000 Difference between depreciation allowed and claimed 34,906 The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the expenditure on spare parts had probably been inflated and the luggage collections of Rs. 15,000 had entirely been kept out of accounts. He further observed that at the time the accounts were made up the directors must have been aware that the profits as per books were very much less than the real profits, as the book profits had been shown at a lesser figure by inflation of the first and the third items and suppression of the second item. In view of these considerations, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the Income-tax Officer justified in rejection the appellants contention regarding the adequacy of dividends declared and in applying the provisions of section 23A.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with High Court

arguments.claim: Dividend less than 60% of assessable income minus taxes; first condition for section 23A satisfied

anchor.surface_text: The High Court first held that on the figures the dividend declared was less than 60 of the assessable income minus the taxes, and the first condition relevant to the application of section 23A was, therefore, satisfied.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have

arguments.claim: Profits displayed in books not only relevant profits; concealed profits (nearly Rs.40,000) must be added to book profits to arrive at correct profits; ITO had material to conclude larger dividend not unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: Then the High Court considered the question whether, on account of the smallness of the profits made, the payment of any larger dividend than Rs. 45,000 would have been reasonable. In this connection the High Court repelled the contention of the assessee that the profits displayed by the assessee in its books of account were the only profits which could come in for consideration. It held that the concealed profits totalling nearly Rs. 40,000 had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the correct figure of the profits of the assessee. The High Court concluded that the Income-tax Officer certainly had material before him on the basis of which he was entitled to conclude that it would not have been unreasonable for the assessee to have declared a dividend larger than that which had actually been declared. In the result the High Court answered the question in the affirmative and against the assessee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with High Court

arguments.claim: Additions for luggage collections and spare parts etc. should not be added to book profits as they represent only notional income

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Srinivasan raised two contentions before us first that the additions in respect of luggage collections and expenditure on spare parts, tyres, tubes, etc., disallowed should not be added to the book profits because they represent only notional income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: come. We are unable to agree to this companytention. The companymercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into companysideration are the re

arguments.court_reasoning: Real commercial or accounting profits include deliberately omitted items; commercial principles do not prevent adding them

arguments.claim: On the findings, ITO not entitled to deem distribution more than commercial profits (around Rs.60,000)

anchor.surface_text: The second contention of the learned counsel for the assessee was that on the findings the Income-tax Officer was not entitled to distribute more than Rs. 60,000 because the assessee was not being made to distribute much more than the commercial profits. This may be so but once the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividend by any company are less than 60 of the assessable income of the previous year, as reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the assessee in respect thereof, and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute a larger dividend than that declared, he has no option but to pass an order that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the assessee of the previous year, as computed for income- tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the company, shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividend amongst the shareholders.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ee. The second companytention of the learned companynsel for the assessee was that on the findings the Income-tax Officer was number entitled to distr

arguments.court_reasoning: Once conditions satisfied, ITO must deem distribution of undistributed assessable income portion

arguments.claim: ITO did not consider reasonableness of dividend from business considerations (previous losses, present profits, surplus, future needs); burden on revenue to prove all conditions including satisfaction on reasonableness per Gangadhar Banerjee precedent

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Srinivasan said that the Income-tax Officer had really not considered the question whether having regard to the losses incurred by the company in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made, the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would be unreasonable. He further urged before us that this Court had held in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee & Co. that the burden lay upon the revenue to prove that all the conditions laid down in section 23A were satisfied before the order was made, and he said that one of the conditions was that the Income-tax Officer, after having examined the question, was satisfied that having regard to the losses incurred by the company in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would not be unreasonable. He further relied on the following observations of Subba Rao J. in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee Co. Would the satisfaction of the Income-tax Officer depend only on the two circumstances, namely, losses and smallness of profit ? Can he take into consideration other relevant circumstances ? What does it mean commercial or accounting profits ? If the scope of the section is properly appreciated, the answer to the said question would be apparent. The Income-tax Officer, acting under this section, is not assessing any income to tax that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have done. He puts himself in the place of the directors. Though the object of the section is to prevent evasion of tax, the provision must be worked not from the standpoint of the tax collector but from that of a businessman. The reasonableness or the unreasonableness of the amount distributed as dividends is judged by business considerations, such as the previous losses, the present profits, the availability of surplus money and the reasonable requirements of the future and similar others. He must take an overall picture of the financial position of the business.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have

arguments.court_reasoning: Point not raised before AAC or Tribunal; too late to raise now; assessee raised different contention before High Court

arguments.claim: Real commercial or accounting profits include concealed or omitted items added back in assessment; must add to book profits

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree to this contention. The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits.

arguments.claim: Once section 23A conditions satisfied, ITO must deem undistributed assessable income (after tax) as distributed dividend

anchor.surface_text: This may be so but once the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividend by any company are less than 60 of the assessable income of the previous year, as reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the assessee in respect thereof, and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute a larger dividend than that declared, he has no option but to pass an order that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the assessee of the previous year, as computed for income- tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the company, shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividend amongst the shareholders.

arguments.claim: ITO did not consider reasonableness like prudent businessman, but assessee failed to raise point before lower authorities; too late now; different contention before High Court (profits mean book profits and carried forward)

anchor.surface_text: He urged that it was quite apparent from the order of the Income-tax Officer that none of the considerations pointed out by this Court had been considered. We agree with him that the Income-tax Officer did not consider the question like a prudent businessman. But, as we have already said, the assessee did not raise this point either before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner or the Appellate Tribunal. If this point had been raised, the facts relating to the considerations mentioned in the observations of Subba Rao J. would have been brought on the record. We feel that it is not too late to permit him to raise this point. Further, it appears from the judgment of the High Court that the assessees contention before it was that the expression profits made in section 23A refers to profits disclosed by the accounts and further to the profits of the previous year that might have been carried forward as such. The fact that this argument was raised before the High Court further shows that the assessee never urged at any previous stage that in view of previous losses and other facts, it would not be reasonable to require the assessee to distribute a larger dividend. ... In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.

holdings.text: The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits. In our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that these two items had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the true commercial or accounting profits of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree to this contention. The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits. In our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that these two items had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the true commercial or accounting profits of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court interprets 'profits made' under section 23A to include real commercial profits, encompassing deliberately omitted or concealed items added back in assessment, rejecting claim that such additions are merely notional.

holdings.text: Once the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that the dividends distributed are less than 60% of assessable income minus taxes payable and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute a larger dividend, he has no option but to order that the undistributed portion of assessable income (reduced by taxes) shall be deemed distributed as dividend among shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: This may be so but once the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividend by any company are less than 60 of the assessable income of the previous year, as reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the assessee in respect thereof, and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute a larger dividend than that declared, he has no option but to pass an order that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the assessee of the previous year, as computed for income-tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the company, shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividend amongst the shareholders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language mandates the deeming order upon satisfaction of the two conditions under section 23A, regardless of whether deemed amount exceeds commercial profits.

holdings.text: The assessee did not raise the point that the Income-tax Officer failed to consider reasonableness from a prudent businessman's standpoint before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner or Tribunal; it is now too late to raise it, especially since a different contention was urged before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Srinivasan said that the Income-tax Officer had really not considered the question whether having regard to the losses incurred by the company in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made, the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would be unreasonable. [...] We agree with him that the Income-tax Officer did not consider the question like a prudent businessman. But, as we have already said, the assessee did not raise this point either before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner or the Appellate Tribunal. [...] We feel that it is too late to permit him to raise this point. Further, it appears from the judgment of the High Court that the assessee's contention before it was that the expression 'profits made' in section 23A refers to profits disclosed by the accounts and further to the profits of the previous year that might have been carried forward as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar prevents raising new grounds not agitated before lower authorities; assessee's failure to raise business considerations earlier and pursuit of different argument in High Court precludes it now.

holdings.text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both conditions under section 23A satisfied on facts; additions to book profits appropriate; no new points admissible; upholds lower courts.

holdings.text: Nothing turns on the difference of Rs. 3,000 in the figure of concealed profits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Minor factual discrepancy immaterial to application of section 23A.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: The Income-tax Officer must consider business considerations such as previous losses, present profits, availability of surplus money, reasonable requirements of the future etc. to determine reasonableness of dividend under section 23A
precedents.cited_holding: The reasonableness or the unreasonableness of the amount distributed as dividend is judged by business considerations, such as the previous losses, the present profits, the availability of surplus money and the reasonable requirements of the future and similar others.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.

outcome.relief_summary: Supreme Court agreed with High Court that section 23A was properly applied, denying relief to the assessee

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree to this contention. The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits. In our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that these two items had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the true commercial or accounting profits of the assessee.
In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.

edges.explanation: h2's explanation of ITO satisfaction supports the affirmative holding in h4
h2 describes the conditions under which the ITO applies the provision (dividends <60% etc.), addressing whether section 23A was properly applied

anchor.surface_text: This may be so but once the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividend by any company are less than 60 of the assessable income of the previous year, as reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the assessee in respect thereof, and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute a larger dividend than that declared, he has no option but to pass an order that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the assessee of the previous year, as computed for income-tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the company, shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividend amongst the shareholders.
In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.
companysideration other relevant circumstances ? What does it mean companymercial or accounting profits ? If the scope of the section is properly app

edges.explanation: Holding that assessee did not raise the point of ITO's failure to consider reasonableness addresses the issue of whether ITO had considered reasonableness from prudent businessman's standpoint

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Srinivasan said that the Income-tax Officer had really not considered the question whether having regard to the losses incurred by the company in earlier years or to the smallness of the profits made, the payment of a dividend or a larger dividend than that declared would be unreasonable. [...] We agree with him that the Income-tax Officer did not consider the question like a prudent businessman. But, as we have already said, the assessee did not raise this point either before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner or the Appellate Tribunal. [...] We feel that it is too late to permit him to raise this point. Further, it appears from the judgment of the High Court that the assessee's contention before it was that the expression 'profits made' in section 23A refers to profits disclosed by the accounts and further to the profits of the previous year that might have been carried forward as such.
In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.
In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.
